node.title: Met Opera’s Conductor Drops Out of ‘Figaro’
node.alt: Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director, will not conduct, as planned, a revival of Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro” in January.
node.description: Yannick Nézet-Séguin said a nearly four-week break from the podium would allow “time for me to re-energize” after a busy autumn.
node.content: ["Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin, the Metropolitan Opera\u2019s music director, will not conduct, as planned, a revival of Mozart\u2019s \u201cLe Nozze di Figaro\u201d in January, the company announced on Monday evening.", "N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin will be \u201ctaking a brief, almost four-week sabbatical from all conducting duties commencing Dec. 19,\u201d the Met said, and quoted him as adding, \u201cThis short break will allow time for me to re-energize as we return in the new year with more inspiring art.\u201d", "The Philadelphia Orchestra, of which N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin is also music director, announced that Xian Zhang would take over his scheduled concerts on Dec. 31 and Jan. 2, but said that his time off would not affect his appearance with the orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 11, nor two subsequent weeks of subscription concerts in Philadelphia in January.", "N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin \u2014 who earlier in his career was known for keeping a particularly hectic schedule, and sometimes canceling \u2014 is currently in the midst of leading the Met\u2019s run of Matthew Aucoin and Sarah Ruhl\u2019s \u201cEurydice.\u201d It is the second company premiere he has conducted this fall, after opening the season with Terence Blanchard and Kasi Lemmons\u2019s \u201cFire Shut Up in My Bones.\u201d", "He also led the Met\u2019s forces in outdoor performances of Mahler\u2019s Second Symphony and a nationally telecast version of Verdi\u2019s Requiem for the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, as well as concerts in Philadelphia, at Carnegie and in Montreal, where he is the music director of the Orchestre M\u00e9tropolitain.", "He conducts Puccini\u2019s \u201cTosca\u201d at the Met from Thursday through Dec. 18, as well as a new production of Verdi\u2019s \u201cDon Carlos\u201d that opens on Feb. 28.", "For the \u201cFigaro\u201d run, which opens on Jan. 8, N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin will be replaced by Daniele Rustioni \u2014 who is at the Met to conduct a new production of \u201cRigoletto\u201d starting New Year\u2019s Eve \u2014 and (for the final performance, on Jan. 28) Gareth Morrell. Five more \u201cFigaro\u201d performances scheduled for April will be conducted by James Gaffigan."]
